title: Data Visualization

Why visualize data?

title: Data Visualization
text:
Anscombe‚Äôs quartet


 



Code
library("datasauRus")
datasaurus_dozen %>% 
  ggplot2::ggplot(aes(x = x, y = y, color = dataset)) +
  ggplot2::geom_point() +
  ggplot2::theme_void() +
  ggplot2::geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "gray", fill = "gray", alpha = .5) +
  ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "none", text = element_text(size = 30)) +
  ggplot2::facet_wrap(~dataset, ncol = 4)












Packages: datasauRus, anscombiser.
More information: Same Stats, Different Graphs, socviz.co.

title: Data Visualization
text:
Exploratory versus explanatory

Exploratory in the sense of data exploration. Exploratory in the sense of visualization exploration (as in previous example, where the same data can be plotted in several ways). In both cases, you can create ugly plots.
We focus on explanatory data viz (also bridge to next). Beautiful plots!






Source: Natalia Kiseleva






Source: Scott McCloud



Exploratory: examine the structure of your data.
Explanatory: tell a story with your data.




More resources: clauswilke.com (telling a story and making a point), susielu.com (different interpretation of exploratory/explanatory).

title: Data Visualization
text:
Exploratory versus explanatory







Source: storytellingwithdata.com

More resources: clauswilke.com (telling a story and making a point), susielu.com (different interpretation of exploratory/explanatory).

title: Data Visualization
text: Exploratory versus explanatory

title: Data Visualization
text:
üí¨

What is more important? An eye or an algorithm?
What are the consequences of overrelying on statistical techniques? What are the consequences of overrelying on visualizations?

title: BDS Toolbox 2025
text:
This site hosts all course materials for BDS Toolbox 2025, a master‚Äôs-level introduction to data visualization and essential data science tools.
Use the navigation bar above or the links below to find what you need.




Instructor: Anne Johansson

Semester: Spring 2025

Format: Lectures + hands-on labs

Main Topics:

Effective data visualization

Reproducible workflows

Git & GitHub for collaboration

Quarto for professional documents and slides








View the syllabus




Lecture 1: Introduction




Browse the repository






Browse the slides before and after class.

Clone or fork the repo to practice Git workflows.

Open .qmd files locally and re-render them with Quarto to experiment.

Submit exercises or labs via GitHub pull requests, following the instructions in the syllabus.



Tip: If a slide link doesn‚Äôt work, make sure you‚Äôve run quarto render and pushed the generated docs/ folder to GitHub.
